column2: Unlocks new buildings for local temple holdings
Aerodrome bonuses only apply if your capital is in this province

The great holds of the Dwarfs are peerless fortresses, capable of withstanding all but the most determined assault. Sadly, some of these holds have fallen into the greenskin hands and repurposed for their foul purposes.
The Dwarfs rarely found a new hold, preferring to reclaim homes lost to their enemies in ages past.
The miners in this province are working relatively shallow layers of the earth, primarily discovering alluvial deposits.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!
The miners in this province are working somewhat deep layers of the earth, primarily discovering sedimentary deposits.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!
The miners in this province are working deep layers of the earth, primarily discovering igneous extrusive deposits.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!
The miners in this province are working very deep layers of the earth, primarily discovering igneous intrusive and metamorphic deposits.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!
Extensive machine pumps have replaced the crude hand pumps that keep this province's mines dry.
Miners in this province are working a deposit of cassiterite, an ore which can be smelted into tin.
Miners in this province are working scattered deposits of native gold, pure metal which requires no smelting.
Miners in this province are working scattered deposits of "Fool's Gold" (Pyrite), an important source of sulfur for our powder mills.
Miners in this province are working deposits of tetrahedrite, a common ore which can be smelted into copper and silver.
This hold draws clean, healthy water from subterranean supplies. Thanks to this supply, the population is healthier and better prepared for sieges.
Miners in this province are working deposits of coal.
Miners in this province are working deposits of galena, an ore which can be smelted into lead and silver.
Miners in this province are working deposits of hematite, an ore which can be smelted into iron.
Miners in this province are working deposits of limonite, an ore which can be smelted into iron.
Miners in this province are working large deposits of magnetite, an ore which can be smelted into iron.
Miners in this province are working scattered deposits of rubies.
Miners in this province are working scattered deposits of sapphires.
Miners in this province are working deposits of cinnabar, an ore of mercury important to alchemists.
Miners in this province are working deposits of native copper, pure metal which requires no smelting.
Miners in this province are working deposits of obsidian, a black volcanic glass.
Miners in this province are working scattered deposits of diamonds.
Miners in this province are working scattered deposits of emeralds.
Miners in this province are working deposits of garnierite, an ore which can be smelted into nickel.
Stonecutters in this province are working deep deposits of granite.
Stonecutters in this province are working deep deposits of marble.
Dwarf ale is legendary. It is not only flavoursome and intoxicating, but highly nutritious. In times of hardship, dwarfs have been known to survive for seasons on a diet of nothing but ale.
This province's major harbour has been upgraded with cranes and other machines that allow it to handle more cargo than less advanced harbours.
This province has an extensive network of subterranean roads, allowing its denizens to travel regardless of the surface weather.
This earth beneath this province has been carefully explored and tunnelled to protect against threats from above and below the surface.
Every truly great dwarf hold has an imposing main entry. The great gate is a significant defensive work and a statement of the hold's artistic values.
The tunnels in this province connect a series of well-designed watchposts. These towers provide advanced warning of attack and can be used as sally points during a siege.

The core of this hold's defence is a cunningly-designed nexus of chambers, including a cistern and significant stores. In the early stages of a siege, this keep provides a highly secure refuge for the most vulnerable, but it can also be used as a place of final resistance against a determined invader.
Local coal supplies are being used to a wide range of industrial purposes, greatly improving this province's productivity.
Hot water from deep underground is brought to living areas to provide washing water and warmth for dwellings.

Running water, whether above or below the surface, is being harnessed on a large scale in this province. Mechanical power generated from water wheels has a limited range of applications but it is highly reliable.

Dwarfs are renowned for their skills below the surface, but they are also capable of manufacturing and piloting reliable aircraft. A well-designed aerodrome in this province is a huge boost to communications.
This province has drydocks and other facilities required for building and fitting out large numbers of coal-powered vessels.

column1: # MILITARY TRADITIONS  - low cost but high build time #

column2: This province has a fine tradition of building and using heavy guns. Its gunners are much sought-after as instructors in less capable armies.
This province has a fine tradition of training handgunners. Its blackpowder-armed regiments are exceptionally-drilled and can turn out a deadly hail of fire.
This province is home to an exceptional warrior tradition. On the battlefield, these elite professional soldiers provide an example to their more ordinary comrades.

Surface-dwelling races rarely have a problem finding a place of assembly. Even the worst-planned Tilean city has empty space outside of its walls in which the citizens can gather. But below ground, almost every space must be carved out intentionally or reworked from a natural cave. The greatest of dwarf holds feature great halls in which a throng can gather for all sorts of social and political occasions.

Venerating those who have come before is a central part of dwarf culture. Traditionally, statues of honored ancestors are given a proud place in a hold. The Dawi Zharr observe the same custom but sculpt no statues, instead displaying the petrified bodies of those who have fallen victim to the Sorcerer's Curse.
Every ruler benefits from a glorious chamber in which to receive audiences. While dwarf notions of aesthetics differ from those of other races, they still build great throne rooms.
This province is home to a great temple of Grimnir, the patron of dwarf warriors and slayers.
This province is home to a great temple of Grungni, the patron of dwarf miners and artisans.
This province is home to a great temple of Valaya, the mother goddess of the dwarfs.
This province is home to a great temple of Hashut, the Dark Father of the Chaos Dwarfs.
The growth of a great city requires significant investment in developed infrastructure.
The great cities of the Old World are centers of trade, military power, and education.
Although moneylenders are a common sight throughout the Old World, the established banks of the largest human cities are far more sophisticated and wealthy.
While uncommon, some human cities have natural fortifications vast enough to support farming as well as more common urban trades.
The growth of urban centers removes humans from their natural environment. Establishing public gardens helps to reconnect people with nature
While the sun provides a fair guide to the time of day, the precision of a clock saves citizens from wasting time waiting for appointments
The transition from seigneurial justice to professional courts is a great boost to commerce

In an age of artillery and magical destruction, ordinary walls have limited defensive value. However, even fairly basic walls can constrain the movement of goods and allow for more efficient taxation.

While most Dwarfs live in their traditional lands, either as a continuation of their long ancestral line or as refugees from fallen holds, some have migrated to human lands. In the most part, their reputation as skilled craftsmen secures Dwarfs the status of welcome guests

Halflings have lived so long in the lands of men that their origins are somewhat obscure. While they are sometimes scapegoated for crimes, halflings tend to be good citizens specializing in service work. They are especially renowned as cooks.
Modern methods of production organize veritable armies of workers into factories and turn whole neighbourhoods into barracks

The Opera was the first form of music to be performed for the public in specialized musical theatres. Transforming what had once been the privilege of the nobility and wealthy burghers into mass culture means transforming the motley plebian class into devoted citizens.
Battles are too random. The plow is too pedestrian. The race track is the true proving ground of equine quality.
Growing cities inevitably become unhealthy. Proper sanitation infrastructure will ease the problem, but cannot eliminate it.
With the growth of the city, the old ritual brawls of village life are slowly transformed into sports with proper codes of conduct, distinctive teams, and even fanatical supporters.
Without streetlights no citizen wants to be out at night. Lighting up the city creates new opportunities for lawful commerce after dark.

Some are adorned with beautiful objects of art, others with battlefield trophies, still others are designed for austere elegance. The palaces of men are as varied as the human race itself, but they are universally built to impress.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!
No palace is complete without a place for viewing fine artwork. Showing off your collection is a fine way to make a lasting impression.

Lords of the dark ages contented themselves with feasting for entertainment, but this is an era of more refined pleasures. A custom-built hall for musical performance is a must for the sophisticated nobleman.
A crypt is a somewhat old-fashioned feature for a modern palace, but it is comforting to know that one's remains will lie in a place of honour.
The Universities of the Old World provide the wealthy with education in a range of subjects.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!
Dwarfs were the first people of the Old World to develop engineering, but in recent years Humans have taken up the profession as well.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!
Arithmetic is one of the core subjects at an Old World university. Further investment in the School of Arithmetic will bring in better instructors and produce superior graduates.
Graduates from the School of Geometry are superior architects.
Turning out graduates with polished grammar will impress the nobility.
History is a newer discipline in Old World universities. Most of the instruction focuses on military campaigns, helping to prepare graduates for battlefield command.
While not the most prestigious academic discipline, Law produces graduates ready for key posts in civic life.

The first trained logicians were priests - not merely the learned Verenans, but also members of other faiths. The university takes techniques developed for religious dispute and applies them more broadly.

For centuries the humans of the Old World have relied on the priesthood of Shallya for healing, but academic study of the human body has started to produce professional physicians of "variable talent".
Professional musicians are not new in the Old World, but the development of formal musical training is opening new possibilities for composition and performance.
Most sailors learn their trade as apprentices, learning the craft of handling a ship and only understanding navigation as an art. Mathematical training produces far more precise navigators.
Rhetoric is the skill of making a persuasive argument. It is particularly important when dealing with the masses of the city.

Canal-building through musclepower alone is extremely time consuming and produces channels of limited depth. The steam-powered inventions of engineers make the work much faster and allows for deeper canals capable of carrying heavier ships.
The rise of engineering provides new construction techniques and architectural insights. These methods produce low-lying defensive systems that can withstand artillery.
Developments in artillery and battle magic are reducing the usefulness of high stone fortifications, but a stout keep still serves as a base of operations for a city's defenders.
While a city's curtain walls once provided sure defence against invasion, they are almost useless against artillery. More advanced defences will be required to really secure a great city.
Formal training for handgunners greatly improves their rate of fire and battlefield performance.
A large centralised cannon foundry guarantees high quality artillery production.
Establishing a formal parade grounds and barracks allows for the expansion of your professional forces.
Large cities have ample manpower for military purposes, but lack a supply of trained horsemen for cavalry forces. Establishing a riding school will make good this shortage.
Expanding the city's port is a boon to trade and provides more naval transport vessels.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!
Part functional building, part landmark, a great lighthouse is a great boost to local trade.
A whole quarter has grown up around the city's port, full of sailors and dockworkers. These tough men make excellent conscripts in times of war.
Smuggling is a major problem at the most important commercial ports. Establishing a regular harbour patrol improves your revenues and helps to protect the city.

The gods of the Old World are not jealous. Most of their worshippers will pray to many gods in the course of a single day, invoking the power of whichever deity seems right for the moment. It is common for the temples of a great city to cluster together for convenience, though priesthoods with conflicting political interests are usually buffered by their more amicable peers.\n§GBuilding this upgrade will unlock new options.§!

The Gods of the Old World inspire fierce loyalty among their followers and there's never a shortage of warriors ready to defend their temples. Indeed, the faithful are so many that orders nominally devoted to protection often participate in wars of aggression. Chapter-houses of Templar Knights can be found in all the cities of the Old World.
Damu is the mother-goddess of Albion, the primordial spirit of the Earth who gave birth to all life. The Gaels revere her above all other deities.
Dazh is the warm-hearted fire god of the North. For the Gospodar and Ungol people, Dazh represents the traditions of hospitality that allow humans to survive in their frozen lands.
Bretonnia' national goddess is the Lady. While she is only worshipped by the nobility, having such wealthy sponsors has led to many beautiful Grail Chapels being built across the country.

Handrich is the Old World's god of trade and commerce. Devoted worshippers of Handrich are rare outside of major commerce centers, though his shrines collect plenty of coin from merchants who wouldn't dare get on his bad side.
Manann is the mythical son of Taal, given dominion over the seas and the tides. His cult is naturally popular on the coasts, though aspects of Manann are also worshipped by riverside peoples.

Morr is the God of Death and the little deaths of sleepers and dreamers. He is sovereign of prophecy and protects the fallen from necromancers. He is the oldest god of the Classical Pantheon, husband to Verena and father to Myrmidia and Shallya.

Myrmidia is a deity of tremendous influence. She is the national goddess of Estalia and Tilea, but unlike the patrons of Bretonnia and the Empire, Myrmidia has a strong following in other realms. She embodies humanity's intellec and civilization, and in particular the art of war. Myrmidia is the mythical daughter of Morr and Verena, and sister to Shallya.

Sigmar Heldenhammer is an ascended mortal. Before his ascension, he was a great warrior who unified twelve tribes into what would become the Empire. Sigmar is now the patron god of the Empire, a fierce protector who inspires tremendous courage and determination.

Despite the grandeur of other faiths, Shallya is the universal goddess of the Old World. Her priests are numerous and widely-admired and her shrines attract a steady stream of generous donations. If the Shallyans were interested in wielding their influence, such high standing might attract jealousy. Shallya is seen as the sister of Myrmidia, and daughter to Morr and Verena.
Great Temple of Taal and Rhya

Taal and Rhya may be the oldest gods of humanity. Taal is the male aspect of hunting and virility, his consort Rhya a female aspect of fertility and the fields. They are worshipped across the old world, though their cult is dwindling in urban places. It is rare to find a shrine dedicated to one but not the other.

column1: #no great temple of Tor because he doesn't have much of a cult

column2: Ulric is the White Wolf of the North, a god so fierce and warlike that he attracts the worship of the warlike Norscans. When Sigmar was merely a man, he prayed to Ulric and the two gods are closely allied.

Ursun is the bear god of the North. Most popular in Kislev, he represents stoic endurance in the face of hardship. He is a wild god whose worship is focused on sacred places, especially the caves of bears. Even in the cities his worshippers congregate outdoors.

Verena is the spirit of learning and judgment. The goddess is paired with Morr as the parents of the Classical Pantheon and her famous daughters are Myrmidia and Shallya. Verena's cult is small and centered on places of learning and justice.

Greenskin biology is strange and inexplicable. Squig biology is outright bizarre. These weird spherical creatures are almost all fanged mouth and savage disposition. They come in all manner of sizes, ranging up to monsters bigger than a Bilbali Pazo. Most greenskins eat a great deal of squig flesh, but they also chain these beasts to be used in battle.

Most goblins are chattering, annoying creatures. Goblin Jesters take these traits beyond excess. These insufferable prats naturally rare and rarely survive more than a month at the side of a warboss before having their necks broken. Among greenskins, being able to maintain a steady stream of replacement Jesters is a sign of great prestige.

Greenskins naturally take out their aggressions on one another, but a warboss who really wants to toughen up da ladz will have a gladiatorial setup to thin out the weakest boyz and help their stronger brethren grow.

The Old World is home to all manner of fungi and slimes, some of which can grow to prodigious size. Night Goblins are experts at cultivating fungal life, though their twisted minds turn this knowledge to finding hallucinogens and raising monstrous squigs.

When greenskins take over a dwarf hold, it's common for the goblins among them to design fiendish traps to "improve" the defences. While these devices certainly make the hold more dangerous for potential attackers, they also take their toll on the new inhabitants.

Contrary to popular opinion, orcs also have their thinkers and their doers. The kunnin' warboss might not be eloquent, but he is a thinker. The Orc Brute is on the other end of the scale, massive and powerful but content to bash whoever he is told to bash without getting caught up in trying to be too clever.

Wetlands are a particularly favourable environment for trolls, full of game and free from the civlized races which attempt to control troll populations. Worse yet, "River Trolls" adapted to amphibious life have an eye-wateringly foul stench and a thick couting of protective slime, making them even more dangerous foes.
Almost every troll is too stupid to work magic. But hag who live long enough and grow big enough soak up the foul energies of death and can wield them powerfully - if clumsily.

It is not known whether Stone Trolls are a distinct subspecies of their breed or merely ordinary trolls who have spent long periods of time subsisting on a mineral diet. Regardless, these creatures have all the strength, stupidity, and regenerative ability of normal trolls, combined with a rocky hide that makes them even more resilient.

Squigball!!! This vicious team sport is one step removed from a gang brawl, but it does a fine job of channeling greenskin aggression into a (usually) non-murderous direction. This is very good news for the tribe's smaller members.
This crude totem has been thrown together in honor of the greenskin god of brutal cunning, Gork. Or perhaps it's to Mork?
This crude totem has been thrown together in honor of the greenskin god of cunning brutality, Mork. Or perhaps it's to Gork?

Most of the time, a Warboss shows his status with his physical stature, some personal decoration, and by bashin' whoever gets in his way. But successful warbosses do fit out crude audience chambers with their grotesque trophies and some grow to enjoy lording their status over lesser beings. When the tribe has captured a great holding of some more sophisitcated race, any manner of building might end up converted into a really grand throne room.
There are no priests of Mork and Gork, but Warchanters come close. These greenskins can hear the primal rhythm of the Waaagh! and drum them out to stir up the reast of the boyz.
By expending immense society influence, you can build an upgrade to this province's Great Work.
This power enables an option to right-click on your county titles where Great Works are present and spend society currency to add or improve engineering upgrades.

Spending 10000 society currency will result in instantly building a Great Work upgrade and add an extra upgrade slot to the Great Work. Alternatively, you may spend 2000 currency to improve an existing upgrade so that it adds an extra upgrade slot.
Sum of dis 'uge place fell off! Itz soft, jus' loik da gitz we took it frum!
